reviewText: Universal has done it again---volume two of their nifty sci-fi has escaped! Run for your lives, or, in this case, run for this collection. See Dr. Cyclops shrink an entire safari to itty-bitty midgie people. Fear the Cult of the Cobra's horrific curse. Stagger through The Land Unknown after crashing into the crater of a dead volcano! Flee from The Leach Woman, whose search for eternal youth ends in death and madness. And swat The Deadly Mantis, nature's most vicious predator. OK. So these may not be cinematic triumphs; in fact, some are downright awful, cheesy, unrealistic and silly. But, they are never dull, sometimes sorta thrilling, and always good for a giggle or two. Various familiar faces going up or down the old celebrity scale are clearly visible: a young David Janssen, Craig Stevens, Coleen Gray, William Hopper and countless others flash by, pursuing or being pursued by monsters and mayhem. Popcorn, or perhaps a stiff drink or two, is suggested.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ok, these flicks are not up to the level of EARTH VERSUS THE FLYING SAUCERS or THE DAY THE EARTH STOOD STILL (or THEM!, for that matter), but it's a fun collection of Grade B and Below features that will entertain any sci-fi/horror buff.  I bought the collection for primarily to own THE LEECH WOMAN, with Colleen Gray and Grant Williams, but it's good to have a copy of the occasionally weird DR. CYCLOPS on hand also.  The pictures are very crisp, but it would have been nice to have a few extra added attractions.

reviewText: I love these old timey "horror" movies. They remind me of my childhood when I spent many Saturday afternoons in the family room laughing with all the drapes closed, a big bowl of popcorn, all the sofa cushions on the floor and a group of neighborhood friends watching these silly movies.These movies are perfect to watch with your young kids because they really are not scary at all. Young kids feel "brave" when they are not afraid of the paper-mache looking monsters in these movies!

reviewText: Most 50's Sci Fi were all classics especially Universal movies.There isn't a bad one in this collection. My favorite the LeechWoman which to me is really a horror movie but who cares it'sgreat. Doctor Dyclops is a overlooked classic kinda like theIncredible Shrinking man with the special effects. Cult of theCobra is a really good mystery horror type movie with a Womanwho can turn into a snake and takes revenge on some soldierswho crashed a sacred ceremony. Deadly Mantis is good oldbig monster vs army Sci Fi. Land Unknown I've only seen onceor twice but it's got BIG DINOSAURS so how bad could it be?These are movies the kind of movies kid should be watching!!
summary: Title says it all Sci Fi Classics!

reviewText: Dr. Cyclops (1940)The brilliant physicist Dr Thorkel (Albert Dekkar) summons four explorers to Peru. They discover a rich source of radium and a half-mad Thorkel who shrinks them down to one-fifth their normal size when they threaten to stop his unorthodox experimentation.Cult of the Cobra (1955)While stationed in Asia, six American GIs witness the secret ritual of Lamians (worshipers of women who can change into serpents). When discovered by the cult, the High Lamian Priest vows that "the Cobra Goddess will avenge herself". Once back in the United States, a mysterious woman enters into their lives and accidents begin to happen. The shadow of a cobra is seen just before each death.The Land Unknown (1957)On a naval expedition to Antarctica, three men and reporter Maggie Hathaway (Shirley Patterson) crash-land in a crater 1000-m below sea level. There, they encounter steamy tropical forest, dinosaurs, carnivorous plants, and human footprints, as Maggie's clothes become more and more abbreviated.The Deadly Mantis (1957)The calving of an Arctic iceberg releases a giant praying mantis, trapped in suspended animation since prehistoric times. It first attacks military outposts to eat their occupants, then makes its way to the warmer latitudes of Washington and New York. A paleontologist (William Hopper) works together with military units to try to kill it.The Leech Woman (1960)A faded beauty (Coleen Gray) leaves a trail of murder from Africa to the United States when she discovers a compound that will restore her lost youth--when consumed with fluid from the pineal gland of the newly dead! I've been waiting for this Saturday Afternoon Matinee favorite for years!  Seeing this on the Saturday afternoon's "Shock!  Theater" which aired a different classic Sci-Fi/Horror movie each weekend, I never forgot the cool scene where the old woman is transformed from a decrepit hag to a ravishing beauty!Grab some snacks! Get comfortable and kick back for some cool `50's sci-fi b-movie classics that will give you a few chills and more than a few chuckles! I highly recommend this dvd collection to fans of classic sci-fi and `50's camp! I recently just got my dvd set from Best Buy for only $19.99!  Check it out! You may still be able to get this awesome set for just under $20.00 bucks before the inventory runs out!

reviewText: I bought this set for the 1957 giant bug film, "The Deadly Mantis". As a kid, there was nothing more exciting that to see a 100' long praying mantis resting on the side of the Washington Monument. The other films are ok, but they were more "drive-in" fare than anything else. I do recommend Universal for putting these films into general release.
summary: Science Fiction Movies at their best.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I learned about this release a month-and-a-half after it came out, but when I went to Best Buy, it was already sold out. I had to pay 28 buck plus shipping on ebay to get it. Wow!The same thing that happened with the first one is happening with the second one. In a few months, rip-off artists will be asking for $100 or more for this. Some dirtbag on ebay is already asking 60 bucks for it.I contacted Best Buy and alerted them to this, that there is a market for both volumes one and two, but that money grubbers bought them in bulk to force them into "out-of-print RARE" status so they can make huge profits.Universal needs to release these collections again and put these jerks out of business. What's a shame is many people like me have waited years for the titles in both volumes to come out, and when they finally do, the releases are so limited that they sell out within a couple months or less before many people realize they're available.But what's most perplexing is the fact that, after seeing how quickly Volume 1 went into out-of-print status, Universal does the same thing with Volume 2. Unreal.It makes me wonder if somebody or some people working for Best Buy, or maybe some people working for Universal, are the ones responsible for this, that some in the know bought up the collections themselves so they can rip off consumers?
Title: N/A

reviewText: There is a good variey of old school sci-fi in this set. While the best of the bunch production-wise is Dr. Cyclops (awesome flick!), most of the others are of the lower b-grade drive-in variety. Yes, they are bad movies, but the best kind of bad movies. The Deadly Mantis is tons of fun and The Land Unknown was surprisingly hilarious, with the guy lumbering around in the rubber t-rex costume being the highlight of the show! If you are the kind of person who can appreciate this kind of stuff then this set is gonna be well worth the money. I bought my copy used on Amazon and it came in near mint condition at a great price. Two Thumbs Up!
summary: Lots of fun packed into this set

reviewText: The Best Buys where I live were not sold out when I discovered this new set was out. Yesterday. They had several in stock. And while I also agree that Universal could've packaged these little nuggets in individual units to protect the discs better, I'm also thankful they're even out at all. No one shows these old gems on TV anymore. I cut my teeth on these flicks growing up and it's thanks to them that I learned to appreciate the sci-fi/horror genres. It's wonderful to be able to pop one in when I'm in the mood for some old time b&w fun (although  "Dr.Cyclops" is in Technicolor). The only real classic here is the 1940 "Dr.Cyclops" but "The Leech Woman" with Coleen Gray going full blast is almost worth buying the set for. I will be watching more closely now for volume 3. There's more good stuff from that era waiting to be appreciated again. Enjoy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is the second volume of Best Buy exclusive Sci-Fi DVD sets. The first one had some classic films that horror/sci-fi fans had been waiting for, for a long time. This set is not quite as good but, still has enough going for it to buy without hesitation. There are at least 3 very good films in this set and the other two are still entertaining. The DVD transfers are very good.I would like to address some complaining about "Vultures" buying up the stock at Best Buy to make a profit. I really see nothing wrong with someone who had the forethought to buy more than one of these sets to sell and make a profit. Not only does it help people who don't have a Best Buy near them able to obtain a copy but, it might make the companies producing these sets, make a larger production run. I bought 10 copies of the first volume and sold them on eBay to the highest bidders. I sold them because some people couldn't find them and they all sold for under $35. I know they have gone up in price now but, that is something you really can't predict. This practice is being done with any product that is in demand and people should not get their nose out of joint because someone thought of it before them. I don't know anyone who wouldn't want to turn $20 into $200........I would do this all day long, if possible. A simple case of "Sour Grapes" perhaps!? I have been selling Horror and Superhero collections for 20 years. It's a hit and miss game like the stock market. You win some you lose some. In all fairness, I think that it is the studios who release this stuff to one chain store who are screwing with the consumer. This set and the first set should have been released to all stores who wanted to carry it. I hope they learn from this and do a third set that will be widely available.
summary: NOT AS GOOD AS VOLUME ONE BUT, IT'S WELL WORTH BUYING!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I enjoyed this set of volume 2 sci-fi adventures, especially "the Cult of the Cobra" where a beautiful woman turns into a snake and seeks revenge on none members/army buddies who watched the cult's ceremonies. She meets and entrances one of the "army buddies" and he falls in love with her beauty, not realizing she is killing all his friends, making it look like accidents. Anyway, the other movies are pretty interesting too, " the Leech woman" was similiar to "Wasp Woman" in that a woman is killing people (in a very weird way) in order to continue her youthful looks!

reviewText: What another treat to finally be able to obtain these rare gems ofyesteryear and not have to worry about profanity,sex and nudity,andcrude,dirty jokes that so often plague all of the mostly uninspiredtrash that Hollywood now churns out each and every year!These trueclassics have what a lot of today's films mostly lack and that is:dignity,class,character development,and plenty of meat to the story.One minor note and unfortunely it's kind of like a minor gripe aswell,the heads at UNIVERSAL still have yet to release one otherextremely rare gem that is unfortunately never been available onVHS or yet on DVD.And the rare gem that I'm referring to is CURUCUBEAST OF THE AMAZON!And it really is a shame,since they've prettymuch managed to completely remaster and restore: THE DEADLY MANTIS,DR.CYCLOPS,CULT OF THE COBRA,THE LAND UNKOWN,THE LEECH WOMAN,andin the first collection: TARANTULA,THE MOLE PEOPLE,THE INCREDIBLESHRINKING MAN,THE MONOLITH MONSTERS,and MONSTER ON THE CAMPUS.Headdistributors at UNIVERSAL,if you are reading this please go lookinto your archives and find CURUCU BEAST OF THE AMAZON and do whatneeds to be done to release it on DVD.You've even released IT CAMEFROM OUTER SPACE on a completely separate DVD altogether.So,why notdo the same thing for CURUCU?

reviewText: A message to Michael Chiaro of Lodi,New Jersey wrote a scathing review on the availability of these box sets. Don't blame Best Buy or the "vultures" who are buying these DVD's up to sell at a higher price. Blame Universal for putting out such limited quantities to very popular movies that hundreds of thousands of us across America enjoyed as a child. Can you imagine if Paramount put out 5000 copies of The Godfather? Would that be fair to the hordes of people who love that movie? Absolutley not. So why would Universal put out first 5 incredible Sci-Fi movies like The Mole People, Incredible Shrinking Man, Tarantula in such limited quantities, and now movies like Deadly Mantis and Land Unknown and Dr. Cyclops knowing these movies would sell whether or not they were limited.  I understand Michael's anger, however I think it's misguided. It should be aimed at Universal Studios for not making these widely available.
